posts.name: mentor
posts.cooked: If a team has continuous bumpers all the way around their robot which are 5 inches tall when laying on the floor, constructed from ¾” birch plywood, and wishes to cut two notches along the top of the wood that are 1” deep and 4 to 6 inches wide each, both on the front side only, to allow the arm to go below the top of the bumpers, and not below the top of the frame perimeter, is this allowed? The bumpers would be securely mounted 7 inches above the floor when on the robot. The notches are 6" away from the corners.

posts.name: Sanchit Arora
posts.cooked: That might cause some weird issues with bumper rules stating that only minor protrusions/pockets into the bumper that are <=1/4" are allowed. I would instead recommend cutting out an entire slot in the bumpers so that they don’t go all the way around but rather have a small gap where your intake/arm swings through. Hope that makes sense

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: No but you could cut out that section of the bumper and mount it lower than the rest of the bumper.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: Look carefully at the bumper wood height tolerance as well…there’s a way to make that work.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Drakxii:

you could cut out that section of the bumper and mount it lower

Or, since you are further than 6" from any corner, omit that section entirely.

posts.name: mentor
posts.cooked: Are you saying cut a half inch notch (to 4-1/2" tall bumper wood) and also lower bumpers 1/2 inch to get to the 1" needed?

I think he is pointing out this part of the rule.

image 961×177 38.8 KB

image 961×177 38.8 KB

image 961×177 38.8 KB

So technically the bumper could be 4.5 to 5.5 inches tall and still be legal.  If most of your bumper was at the max height and the notch was cut to the min height you would be legal to the letter of the rulebook based on my understanding.

I don’t know if I would be comfortable showing up with bumpers utilizing these limits.  Your LRI might view this rule differently.  I suspect the intent of the rule is to allow teams a good amount of manufacturing tolerance not for clearance features.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: It would also be legal to have bumpers that were a consistent 5" in height, but which were not identically placed in the bumper zone.   There is no rule precluding bumpers either with a stepped appearance (see below) or with bumpers that are sloped (non-horizontal).

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked: We have used bumpers like this.  It invited a ton of scrutiny from inspectors but was ultimately allowed to pass

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Yeah if it stays within the bumper zone…

There is a surprising amount of freedom in the bumper zone rules. All it is gonna take is one season for a team to exploit a few rules to really cause some havoc.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
chadr03:

intent of the rule

The rule says the wood can be 4.5" tall.

We match our Noodle diameter x2 for a clean appearance. It’s usually a quarter inch under nominal or so.

OP, you’ve got plenty of options. The notch will definitely invite scrutiny, but is legal if you have at least 4.5" of wood. I’d do 4.5 all the way around, personally, so that fabric wraps better and it looks cleaner and invites fewer questions.

If you do a deeper notch to less than 4.5, it’s possible you could be forced to remove the notched section at comp.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Building right at 4.5’ runs a risk that an inspector measures it a spot that happens to be 4.48" and says “no good”.  I would definitely leave myself some margin for error (in construction and potentially in measuring).

posts.name: OccamzRazor
posts.cooked:
This is a photo of what 2640 is referring too I believe :

image 811×609 65.7 KB

image 811×609 65.7 KB

image 811×609 65.7 KB

I believe this would be scrutinized heavily at competition.  Any LRIs care to comment?

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
That’s fundamentally the same at this setup we ran for 2018 and 2019 (literally the same bumpers):

image 1030×286 7.48 KB

image 1030×286 7.48 KB

image 1030×286 7.48 KB

For other reasons those bumpers got a lot of scrutiny, but no issues with that trick.

posts.name: OccamzRazor
posts.cooked: besides them being only 4" tall here you mean, which could be redone with some mounting changes to the wood. @thehotbotz2640 I think you have a few answers now!

posts.name: mentor
posts.cooked: Thank you all so much. We are reworking the bumpers now, two days before competition :-). I wish I had asked you before I told them “hey sure - if you can cut a whole side off I’m sure you can notch them.” But we got it now!

posts.name: Alex Cormier
posts.cooked: What was the purpose of doing them that way?

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Neat trick. Gonna stick this in the ole brain archive.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Probably clearance to prevent hang up on hap or the scale platform.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: Yep, and we normally run a 5.5" bumper backing to get a bit more protection and weight anyway.

data.fancy_title: Notches in the top of bumper wood OK?
data.title: Notches in the top of bumper wood OK?
